Cartels operate by mutually agreeing to limit production below where supply and demand would normally intersect. This allows above market prices to be obtained by the members of the cartel.  The challenge of 'running' a cartel is that members are inclinded to cheat and over-produce, since this will lead to higher revenues for that one member-state. Eventually, more and more members will produce in excess of their production agreements, leading to a decline in prices.   (1) Given the historical animosity between Iran and Saudi Arabia (2) Budgetary needs of Iran their would seem to be a low probability of Iran agreeing to cap its production at this time.

Juni 2016 um 09:03:57 MESZ Subject: Opec leaders meet in Vienna as Iran rejects oil output cap | Business | The Guardian https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/jun/02/iran-rejects-oil-output-cap-as-opec-leaders-meet-in-vienna "...The Iranian minister, Bijan Zanganeh, said on the eve of Thursday’s meeting that a production cap would have “no benefit” for Iran – or for the other members of the cartel, which pumps around a third of the world’s oil.
“One of our main ideas is to have country quotas, but I don’t think we can reach an agreement on this subject at this meeting,” the minister said as he arrived in the Austrian capital..."

At today’s meeting of the oil producers’ cartel in Vienna, most eyes will be on Saudi Arabia’s new energy minister, Khalid Al-Falih. But if anyone is to spring a surprise, it could be Iran. Prices have recovered to near $50 a barrel thanks to a lucky (for some) turn of events. Though Iran and Saudi Arabia failed to agree in April on a production freeze, supply disruptions since then in Iraq, Nigeria, Libya and elsewhere have in effect done their work for them; OPEC production is roughly flat at January levels despite Iran’s extra output. Logic suggests OPEC should let the rebalancing of the oil market continue at its own pace. But Iran, which is pumping at nearly full capacity, may yet confront Mr Falih by proposing a freeze. It said yesterday that it wouldn’t—but given the antagonism between the two Gulf powers, surprises can’t be ruled out

There is still a lot of uncertainty on oil demand due to manufacturing slow down in China, the world outside the US seeing tough economic conditions, etc. Iran does need to see higher oil revenues and a capping agreement is good for them in many ways.   My prediction is that they will make a lot of noise against it, but there is a good chance they will do what they did 15/16 years ago, which is agree to a quota and resort to breaking it. They had a lot of bilateral arrangements in the embargo Era and the countries on the other side of those deals are feeling sore. They will agree to a quota, claim the bilaterals are outside the quota and continue to oversupply.  It worked well for them in the past, and hurt Saudi Arabia badly. The temptation to do the same is likely to be strong.

http://www.wsj.com/articles/saudi-arabias-powerful-oil-minister-ali-al-naimi-is-fired-1462632035
"Saudi Arabia dismissed its long-serving oil minister Ali al-Naimi on Saturday, marking the departure of one of the industry’s most powerful figures as the country grapples with weak oil prices. Mr. Naimi, who had been the kingdom’s oil minister since 1995, has been a strong voice against lowering Saudi Arabia’s production when prices fall, a move away from its past tactics. Mr. Naimi was the architect of the 2014 shift in policy of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to avoid slashing production amid a global supply glut, a move that has weighed on crude oil markets and depressed prices.
...
The 80-year-old Mr. Naimi had for some time wanted to retire, and his departure, along with Mr. Falih’s appointment were widely anticipated, suggesting market reaction to the moves is likely to be calm, said Jason Bordoff, director of Columbia University’s Center on Global Energy Policy. “Khalid al Falih has been a key part of the team making these decision for many years,” he said. “It represents a continuation of the path they’ve been on.” Mr. Naimi had been saying for some time that he wanted to retire, and Mr. Falih has been within the inner circle of Saudi oil policy-making for a long time. He was being groomed for months, according to people familiar with the matter. The decree said Mr. Falih was relieved from his other post of health minister." http://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-oil-minister-idUSKCN0XY0E1
"Riyadh in 2014 introduced a new oil strategy aimed at defending its market share and allowing cheap crude to balance the market without cutting supplies, regardless of how low oil prices might fall. Falih's appointment is only likely to strengthen this strategy rather than lead to any change in thinking, Saudi watchers and analysts say." http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-05-07/saudi-aramco-chairman-al-falih-replaces-al-naimi-as-oil-minister
"Al-Falih is known to be close to King Salman and his 30-something son Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the deputy crown prince who has been a growing force driving the country’s policies. Prince Mohammed has announced plans for an economic shakeup to reduce the kingdom’s reliance on oil, and has also insisted that Saudi Arabia won’t agree to a freeze in oil output to curb the global glut without the participation of other major producers.
“Al-Falih’s appointment is an assurance of the continuation of the current Saudi oil policy,” Anas Alhajji, the chief economist at Irving, Texas-based NGP Energy Capital Management, said by phone."

It seems as though there is some confusion about the question.  I'm reading the question as Iran formally agrees to a cap before 1 July 2016, but that it may take time for actual production to match the agreed level. According to Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum_industry_in_Iran#/media/File:IRAN_oil%26gas_production.jpg), Iranian production was above 4mb/d in the mid-1970s, fell to around 2mb/d in the early 1980s, recovered to just below 4mb/d in the 1990s and 2000s.  In February, Iran’s production was 3.22mb/d, up from 2.87mb/d in August 2015.  It appears that Iran has said publicly (can’t find a direct quote, didn’t look that hard) that they would like to get back to 4mb/d before they agree to any kind of a cap. In the past few weeks, it appeared that an agreement between Saudi Arabia, Russia, and other major producers (but not Iran) was in the works.  On April 18th, it was reported that the talks had collapsed, with Prince Mohammed calling the Saudi oil minister Ali al Naimi and ordering him to kill the talks.  According to the FT: “oil, analysts say, has become a weapon for Saudi Arabia to wield in its proxy war with Iran.” A low oil price hurts both Saudi Arabia and Iran.  Saudi Arabia runs a large budget deficit, although the country has many years of reserves and probably can borrow.  Iran does not run a deficit but has no reserves.  Economically, neither will be forced to come to an agreement, particularly not before the 1 July question deadline.   Yet Iran is perhaps no worse off by agreeing to a cap compared to continuing the fight.  With production of 4mb/d at the current price of around $40, that is $160m per day of revenue.  If Iran agrees to a cap at current levels (3.22mb/d) and the price goes up to $50, Iran generates $161m per day of revenue.   Saudi Arabia has made its position known: “no cap without Iran.”  This actually makes it more likely that Iran agrees to cap its production than it was before the Doha meeting, where a production freeze might have been agreed without Iran having to put its own cap in place.  Now, for a production freeze to happen, Iran must also agree to a cap.   We must also make an adjustment for the political pressure that might be brought to bear on Iran.  There were many other parties at the Doha meeting, including other OPEC members and Russia, and they all seemed to favor a production freeze.  Perhaps some of these other actors may be able to pressure Iran into softening their 4mb/d position, placating Saudi Arabia, and agreeing to a cap. Ultimately, it seems to me that the chance Iran agrees to cap is still low, but not zero.  I’m going to put it at 15% (implying 85% chance that Iran does not agree to a cap by 1 July).

I recently asked for a clarification of this question. 
Some forecasters are forecasting on the question,  "Will Iran AGREE to cap its oil output before 1July?"   
Others are forecasting on the question, "Will Iran agree to CAP ITS OIL OUTPUT BEFORE JULY 1?"    Here's the reply:  
"The question team has discussed your question and decided not to issue official guidance at this time. Please forecast on the question as written: "Will Iran agree to cap its oil output before 1 July 2016?" 
~~~~~~~
I find this sort of reply most unhelpful, but I don't think that asking the question was a wasted effort, mainly because I am of the opinion that oftentimes GJI is not aware of the grammatical or geo-political issues we alert them to when we ask questions.  By alerting them, perhaps it helps them not get trigger happy and resolve a question pre-maturely, and perhaps it  helps them be clearer in their own minds (though not with us) about what the intent of the question is/was.
~~~~~~~~
My answer to those who are wondering which way this question should be interpreted is that I ASSUME each word in the question is there for a reason.  If they just wanted to know if Iran would cap output, they'd not have inserted the words, "agree to", and  the question would (or should) have been stated "Will Iran cap its oil output before July 1?"   Therefore, I am ASSUMING that GJI is asking if there will be an agreement prior to July 1, in which case it should have been worded, "Will Iran agree before 1 July to cap its oil output?"  If that was the intent of the question, the question as posed contains a grammatical error:  a misplaced modifier.
~~~~~~~
Frankly, at this point I don't think either will happen before July 1, especially putting in place an actual cap.

Technically, they already have agreed to cap output - but only when production reaches pre-sanctions levels around 4mn b/d. I take this question to mean that they will agree to cap output around current levels. Unlikely. OPEC, as an organization, has shown little ability to coordinate despite the drop in oil prices. Any significant cuts at this point which drives global energy prices higher is only likely to benefit smaller shale producers in the U.S., thereby supporting one of the main drivers behind the drop in prices.

Iran has every reason to treat the cap argument as another proxy war with SA and seems likely to want to reduce SA's influence over OPEC or oil trading in general. The state may pay lip service to price stability but is presumably aware that the continuing low price will not just hurt SA politically but also lead to a number of the higher-cost/more speculative oil producers going to the wall, which will lead to greater stabilisation in the price. If Iran can effectively force SA to cut production that is all to Iran's benefit at home and in terms of geopolitical status. It is possible that Iran may choose to agree to a high future cap, but I can't see that being a popular move at home.

It could even be a way for Iran to show it is being reasonable, and put the onus back onto the other producers.

Iran has indicated that it will continue to increase its oil production in order to regain its share of the global market since it is no longer constrained by international sanctions.   It has also indicated that it will continue production and supply to the global market and consider a cap once it has reached a 4 million/bpd output.   It will now participate in the upcoming OPEC meeting (along with non-OPEC members) in April to discuss a freeze in production in order to stabilize global price levels.  Iraq has filled the production of Iranian quota's since the implementation of sanctions.  It now holds the position that it will only participate in the April meeting if all members are involve and agree to a freeze.  Russia, bilaterally supporting Iran on this issue, has also indicated (despite its participation in April) that continued production increases by Iran are justified. The April meeting is bound to be quite contentious while a clear majority agrees to the necessity of a freeze in production in order to stabilize the oil market.  Non-OPEC members who have born the brunt of oversupply in the market, significantly affecting their domestic economies and in some cases the ability to service their international debt and to keep a domestic economy from collapsing - Venezuela, will no doubt be the strongest supporters of a freeze in order to regain market share and stabilize their political and domestic situations.

I am going to start out very skeptical, and may just swing to a big zero.  Here is why: This article talks about Iran's position, which is generally the same as it has been for quite some time, which is that Iran will not agree to production caps until it gets back to its pre-embargo production.  Ok, so what is the number then?  Its 4.0 million barrels per day.  There are several other news sources that indicate Iran has just recently rejected such caps, so they are being pretty clear about it.
http://www.bbc.com/news/business-35801732 But where are we now?  I mean, Iran is ramping up production.  So maybe they will make the 4.0 million mark by the end of June.  This article by the U.S. EIA is very instructive on this discussion.  It shows a ramp-up in production from current levels around 3 million to 4.0 million sometime in 2017.   
https://www.eia.gov/todayinenergy/detail.cfm?id=24592 So in my opinion, the only way this proposition will close affirmative is if Iran very quickly ramps up production, or just give up getting back its past market share.
I think Iran would only consider this kind of move if petrol prices drop to $ 20 levels again, not impossible in the next 4 months, not exactly the most probable scenario.
